awd_abstract_narration:
This project is related to the area of the Uncertainty Principle (UP) in Harmonic Analysis. Briefly, this principle says the sets where a function and its Fourier transform are non-zero cannot be simultaneously small. Stemming from the work of Norbert Wiener in mathematics and Werner Heisenberg in physics, the area of  UP still presents many mathematical challenges. Its problems have a number of applications in adjacent fields. Several classical problems of UP, posed decades ago by such prominent mathematicians as Norman Levinson, Andrei Kolmogorov and Norbert Wiener, remain open. Some of such problems are studied in this project. Modern methods of Complex and Harmonic Analysis that appeared in the last 30 years suggest new approaches to the classical challenges of UP. These problems have a number of important applications in Approximation Theory, Prediction Theory, Spectral Theory of differential operators and Mathematical Physics.
  
Among the proposed topics of research are generalizations of the so-called Gap and Type problems in Harmonic Analysis, an extension of the well-known Gelfand-Levitan theory in the area of spectral problems for differential operators and connections between Krein's canonical systems of differential equations and asymptotics of the Riemann zeta-function. Successful completion of this step of the project will create a systematic view of the large variety of problems in the area of UP based on the new notion of Toeplitz Order discussed in the proposal. The study of Toeplitz Order is a continuation of the study of the so-called Toeplitz approach to UP developed in recent papers of Nikolai Makarov (Caltech) and the principal investigator. The next stage of the applications of the Toeplitz approach contains several classical open problems of Harmonic Analysis and Spectral Theory, including general completeness problems, spectral problems for Schroedinger and Dirac operators and a Toeplitz operator version of the so-called Krein - de Branges theory, which was designed to connect Complex and Spectral Analysis.  Among other applications, the project includes a problem on Uncertainty Quantification in the settings of spectral problems for Schroedinger opearators and canonical systems of differential equations.

por.por_cntn:
One of the important applications of Harmonic and Complex analysis lies in the area of spectral problems for differential operators.The area of direct and inverse spectral problems connects complex and harmonic analysis to mathematical and theoretical physics, signalprocessing and other areas of pure and applied mathematics. New methods based on the use of so-called Toeplitz operators brought a new approachto this classical area in recent years. The next stage of development of the Toeplitz approach to spectral problems   was the main area for this project. 


The breadth of the Toeplitz approach allows one to connect several classical problems in analysis into one general problem. Toeplitztools have been successfully applied in problems on completeness and uniqueness, Riesz bases, sampling and interpolation in spaces of analytic functions. After recent development of the new approach in PI's joint papers with N. Makarov (Caltech), it was used by the PI tosolve several long standing problems, including those studied by such prominent mathematicians as A. Kolmogorov, M. Krein and N. Wiener.


One of the main published products of the project is the paper "Toeplitz order", which appeared in the Journal of FunctionalAnalysis. The paper attempts to systemathize andclassify problems of the Toeplitz approach stemming from various parts of analysis and mathematical physics. A new solution to the classicalGap and Type problem was published in the paper "Spectral gaps for Frostman measures", which appeared in Advances of Mathematics. A paper summarizingrecent results in the area of completeness problems and presenting new results in spectral theory was published by the PI in the proceedingsof the Inernational Congress of Mathematicians in 2018.


Among other significant outcomes is a solution of an 'uncertainty' version of the classical two-spectra problem  for Schroedinger operatorspublished in a joint paper with N. Makarov in the Journal of Spectral Theory. Further development of our methods led to a new understanding of spectral problemsfor canonical Hamiltonian systems. A joint paper in this area is currently under preparation.


PI's graduate student, Burak Hatinoglu, who was partially supported by the project, has defended his PhD in March 2020. He will start a postdoctoral position in the fall of 2020. PI's current Ph. D. students, Ashley Zhang and Sean Nemetz, continue their work in the area of the project. Two M.S. students, C. Wang and L. Sun, graduated during the term of the project under PI's supervision.


During the period of the project the PI gave numerous research talks at seminars and conferences. Two minicourses in the area of the project,oriented toward young researchers and students, were given at research programs at Toulouse and Barcelona. A semester-long research program in the general area of the project was co-organized by the PI at CRM, Barcelona, in the fall of 2019. American participants of the program's workshopin November of 2019 were supported by a grant from the NSF (conference grant application was submitted jointly with C. Liaw). Majority of supported participants were students and women.


Based on recent research partially supported by the NSF, the PI presented an invited lecture at the analysis section of the International Congress of Mathematicians, Rio de Janeiro, 8/2018.
